headline.main: Who Benefits From the Drug Plan? (5 Letters)
headline.print_headline: Who Benefits From the Drug Plan?

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: Re ''Falling Into the Doughnut Hole'' (editorial, Oct. 6):

headline.main: Who Benefits From the Drug Plan?

docs.abstract: Five letters comment on Oct 6 editorial about Medicare drug program; John E LeMoult says it is one of most repugnant laws passed by Congress; Augustana College Prof Daniel E Lee says it makes sense to provide universal coverage up to certain level of expenditure and catastrophic coverage for those with huge prescription drug costs; Dr Marvin S Wool notes that more than 85 percent of beneficiaries will never reach 'doughnut hole'; George Washington University Medical Center associate vice pres Gerald Bass says feature encourages consumers to be prudent in using drugs; drawing; Lenore Brooks questions why American politicians are against providing universal health plan
docs.snippet: To the Editor:     Re ''Falling Into the Doughnut Hole'' (editorial, Oct. 6):

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Robert G. Petersdorf was an internationally known infectious diseases expert who was also one of the most powerful figures in American medicine for many years.

headline.main: American Wins Nobel Prize in Chemistry
headline.print_headline: American Wins Nobel Prize in Chemistry

docs.snippet: Roger D. Kornberg, an American, won the chemistry prize for research on how data in genes is used to make proteins.

docs.lead_paragraph: A new United States-financed program to provide mass integrated treatment of neglected tropical diseases like trachoma, river blindness and elephantiasis will soon get under way in East and West Africa, officials with the Agency for International Development said. Congress has appropriated $15 million for the undertaking, up from $2 million in 2005. Pharmaceutical companies are donating the drugs; the federal funds will help cover the costs of distributing them. CELIA W. DUGGER (NYT)

headline.main: World Briefing | Africa: U.S. Effort To Reduce Neglected Tropical Diseases

docs.abstract: United States will fund new program to provide mass treatment of neglected tropical diseases in East and West Africa through Agency for International Development; budget appropriation of $15 million has been authorized and pharmaceutical companies will donate drugs (S)
